node.title: User defined interface
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Can we define the interface in the form of a function. For example. Let the simulation box contain 2 grains but instead of them separated by a straight interface, can I define say interface as a sin function (wavy type)?
Thank you
Ashish

hello
The interface is defined with a variable right?
You could use a Function and a FunctionIC to initialize said variable
Guillaume

Say for example, I use SmoothCircleIC, the function is a circle with invalue =1 and outvalue = 0. but if I define a sine function, it will be difficult to decide which side of the function is 1 and which side is 0, if eta is my variable on which AC kernels are acting.

node.title: Is possible to use nodal vaule to remove the mesh size dependent stress value?
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE Team,
I ran the THM exemplary case (link) under the folder 'modules/porous_flow/examples/thm_example/2D.i'.
When I reduced the radial length (xmax) from 500m to 300m, I observed the radial effective stress (Srr) value is 4-5 MPa at the wellbore, instead of the previous 0.3 MPa with xmax=500m. The mesh size near the wellbore for xmax=500m is 0.0035 m, while for xmax=300m it is 0.1 m. Therefore, I am wondering if the stress is defined on elements instead of on grids, even though I define Srr at the wellbore (0.1, 0, 0) in the [Postprocessors].
To eliminate the mesh size dependent results, my question is: how can I obtain the stress values at specific grid points (Nodal vaule) rather than the averaged values over elements? By the way, I tried the type = RankTwoAux or NodalPatchRecoveryAux under [AuxKernels], but still not work.
Thanks.

I'm not sure what I am doing wrong or how to fix it.

These errors are pretty common when libMesh has not yet been built. Also, it seems you may have copied-n-pasted from other instructions, being that these three commands were entered simultaneously:
cd $MOOSE_DIR/modules/reactor
make -j4
./reactor-opt --version
We certainly avoid telling folks to set and use MOOSE_DIR. Can I ask what set of instructions you are following? If they are from our website, I'd like to verify they are modern/accurate.

Hopefully that image shows but if not here is the website: "https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial04_meshing/presentation/index.html#/5/2"
I was trying to compile the Reactor Module but it won't let me because it doesn't recognize the "make -j4" command.
it should. Are you using the conda installation path? If so, did you remember to conda activate moose ?

`(base) root@COMECH-0083:~# conda activate moose
(moose) root@COMECH-0083:~# cd $MOOSE_DIR/modules/reactor
make -j4
./reactor-opt --version
-bash: cd: /modules/reactor: No such file or directory
make: *** No targets specified and no makefile found.  Stop.
-bash: ./reactor-opt: No such file or directory`
This is the error it gives me when I  conda activate moose

The cd (change directory) command is failing because the moose_dir environment variable is not set.
In general, do not copy paste blocks of Linux commands you do not understand. You have to go line by line and ask Google or chatgpt what they mean if you do not know.
For now, go to the moose folder with cd, then go to modules/reactor
Then type make there

I am walking through these same instructions, and I come across the bit about "Install MOOSE", which takes you here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/index.html
Which option did you choose? I want to say "Docker", as I think that may be the only instance where you would find yourself as being a root user. But if you choose docker, "libmesh" and the other dependency libraries should already be built.
I chose Linux and MacOS option. I am running MOOSE on WSL Ubuntu.

From what I can tell It says I should have a module named reactor -opt. But that doesn't exist anywhere in my files when I installed MOOSE. I don't know if that's an installation failure or if I need to download it separately.
You are running as root outside of a container (Docker, Apptainer, Singularity, things of this nature), which is dangerous. Can we start again, without using the root user account?

Yes, I'm sorry I am pretty new to all of this. I'm still doing research to figure out how to even use the command terminals to get MOOSE. Thank you for being patient with me!
I am using WSL ubuntu. Should I use WSL command prompt?
When you launch your WSL instance, does it log you in automatically as root? Or are you having to run something like sudo su - in order to do so?

https://www.kapwing.com/w/IWvBtu_nVk
This is how I navigate there.

It doesn't look like your moose environment is populated with the right Conda packages (if any) I was a bit curious when in the video conda activate moose returned immediately :) I saw that, and thought "woah. This is a fast machine!"

conda env remove -n moose
conda create -n moose moose-dev
conda activate moose
If all goes well, next try to build the reactor module:
cd /root/projects/moose/
git clean -xfd            # this cleans out a previous failing build
cd modules/reactor
make -j 6

test/tests/meshgenerators/simple_hexagon_generator/sim_hex.i --mesh-only
-bash: moose/modules/reactor/reactor-opt: No such file or directory

I think it helps to be in the same directory as the input file when you run your application:
cd ~/moose/modules/reactor/test/tests/meshgenerators/simple_hexagon_generator/
../../../../reactor-opt -i sim_hex.i --mesh-only
Reading your prompt very carefully, the issue I think is that you are already in the directory where reactor-opt resides.
(moose) root@COMECH-0083:/moose/modules/reactor# moose/modules/reactor/reactor-opt
                         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

And by providing a relative path:
(moose) root@COMECH-0083:/moose/modules/reactor# moose/modules/reactor/reactor-opt
                                                 ^

...that is a path not preceding with a /, you are instructing the system to actually try and run reactor-opt in the following location (where it does not exist):
/moose/modules/reactor/moose/modules/reactor/reactor-opt

Thank you I understand now.
(moose) root@COMECH-0083:/moose/modules/reactor/test/tests/meshgenerators/simple_hexagon_generator# /moose/modules/reactor/reactor-opt -i sim_hex.i --mesh-only
This code ran the input file.

node.title: AbaqusUMATStress for different constant_properties for each element or grain
node.bodyText:
Dear moose user,
How can I load constant_properties  using a list of data as the euler angle for each element or grain in AbaqusUMATStress.
Is it possible somehow to use the PropertyReadFile to do this?
[Materials]
  [umat]
    type = AbaqusUMATStress
    constant_properties = 'eulerang1 eulerang2 eulerang3' 
    plugin = '../../../plugins/crystal_plasticity'
    num_state_vars = 0
    temperature = temperature
    use_one_based_indexing = true
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [./prop_read]
    type = PropertyReadFile
    prop_file_name = 'euler_angle_file.txt'
    nprop = 3
    read_type = element
  [../]
[]

Best regards,
LifengGan

Those would not be constant properties, but external_fields and you would have to put the Euler angles into a set of AuxVariables. If you want to go with constant_properties you'd have to block restrict the AbaqusUMATStress material and add it multiple times (once for each block) and supply it with different values for the Euler angles each time. If you have a small number of Euler angles this could be done by hand. For a larger number you could either generate an input using a Python script or write a MOOSE Action that adds the AbaqusUMATStress using data read from a file.

node.title: Heated channel with fluid not exiting at outlet
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Navier Stokes is the most appropriate category for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Question
Hi there,
I have been using the Navier Stokes module to simulate a horizontal coolant channel (with inconel walls) being heated up using a FVDirichletBC boundary condition on the inconel. Heat is transferred through a FVConvectionCorrelationInterface to the coolant, which travels along the x direction. The inlet coolant boundary has a temperature defined by a heat flux, and inlet velocity defined with the INSFVInletVelocityBC.
My issue is, at the coolant outlet, the velocity of the fluid speeds up at the bottom, and appears to turn to move back on itself. It's as if the coolant if 'hitting' the outlet boundary, and turning back on itself. This can be seen in the image below. Am I missing something very obvious? Thanks :)

I have set up the following boundary conditions:
[FVBCs]
    [inlet-u]
      type = INSFVInletVelocityBC
      boundary = 'inlet'
      variable = u
      function = ${inlet_velocity}
    []
    [inlet-v]
      type = INSFVInletVelocityBC
      boundary = 'inlet'
      variable = v
      function = 0
    []
    [inlet-T]
      type = FVNeumannBC
      variable = T
      value = '${fparse rho * cp * inlet_velocity * inlet_temp}'
      boundary = 'inlet'
    []
    [no-slip-u]
      type = INSFVNoSlipWallBC
      boundary = 'inner_wall_top inner_wall_bottom'
      variable = u
      function = 0.000001
    []
    [no-slip-v]
      type = INSFVNoSlipWallBC
      boundary = 'inner_wall_top inner_wall_bottom'
      variable = v
      function = 0.000001
    []
    [bottom]
        type = FVDirichletBC
        variable = Ts
        boundary = outer_wall_bottom
        value = 700
    []
    [top]
        type = FVDirichletBC
        variable = Ts
        boundary = outer_wall_top
        value = 700
    []
    [outlet_momentum_u]
      type = INSFVMomentumAdvectionOutflowBC
      variable = u
      u = u
      v = v
      boundary = 'outlet'
      momentum_component = 'x'
      rho = ${rho}
    []
    [outlet_momentum_v]
      type = INSFVMomentumAdvectionOutflowBC
      variable = v
      u = u
      v = v
      boundary = 'outlet'
      momentum_component = 'y'
      rho = ${rho}
    []
    [outlet_p]
      type = INSFVOutletPressureBC
      boundary = 'outlet'
      variable = pressure
      function = '${outlet_pressure}'
    []
[]

Additional information
Mesh size and type:
Reynolds number:
Discretization (finite element CG/DG, finite volume, etc):
Models (turbulence, porous media, etc):
Solver method (fully coupled, segregated, multiapps, etc):
Base input you started from:

Hello
This does look weird indeed.
Is this the steady state solution? Such a state could be an intermediate state moving from the inital condition to the solution we expect

Thank you for the reply! The simulation is transient, and the effect is there at every time step. Could I be missing something else?
Best wishes,
Attached is my executioner:
[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    end_time = 300
    dtmin = 1e-8
    dtmax = 0.1
    petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -options_left'
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'
    line_search = 'none'
    nl_max_its = 15
    l_max_its = 500
    nl_rel_tol = 1e-10
    [TimeStepper]
      type = IterationAdaptiveDT
      optimal_iterations = 7
      dt = 0.5
      linear_iteration_ratio = 1e6
      growth_factor = 1.5
    []
[]

I m not sure what we could be missing.
Can you share your input and your mesh on a github repository?

That'd be great! Thanks for having a look.
https://github.com/oh304/moose_sandbox
@lindsayad or @freiler if you have time to take a look
Could you create your mesh with quad elements instead of tris? FV appreciates as little skew as possible

The artifact does seem to go away if you remove the Boussinesq kernels for the momentum equation. Do you need those kernels? Do you expect natural convection to be significant compared to the forced convection you have in your channel flow?

There is a problem with the BCs, the Boussinesq term gives you a pressure gradient in the vertical direction, but the outlet BC specifies a constant pressure at the outlet, which is not consistent with the vertical pressure gradient due to buoyancy. This results in an acceleration at the outlet.
Some solutions might be:

Specify a pressure field at the outlet that matches the expected pressure gradient due to buoyancy.
Create a boundary condition that corrects the pressure at the outlet for thermal buoyancy.

Note: it does not mean that the flow is not exiting...

This is what you need to do for the solution in the first bullet point
...
[AuxVariables]
    ...
    [hydrostatic_pressure]
      type = MooseVariableFVReal
    []
    ...
[]
...
...
[AuxKernels]
    ...
    [populate_hydro_pressure]
      type = ParsedAux
      variable = hydrostatic_pressure
      coupled_variables = T
      use_xyzt = true
      expression = '-${alpha} * ${g} * ${rho} * y * (T - ${reference_temperature}) + ${outlet_pressure}'
      block = 'coolant'
    []
    ...
[]
...
...
[FVBCs]
    ...
    [outlet_p]
      type = INSFVOutletPressureBC
      boundary = 'outlet'
      variable = pressure
      functor = 'hydrostatic_pressure'
    []
    ...
[]
...

This is the pressure profile with the previous solution (which introduces the artificial acceleration at the outlet):

.. and this is the one with the new one:

Please also consider quad elements as @lindsayad suggested, since the velocity profile is not really smooth in the tri mesh:

Ah! Thank you so much for your responses @tanoret @lindsayad @GiudGiud - much appreciated! That pressure outlet definitely looks better with the hydro-static pressure functor! I will implement these changes now, including the quad elements :)
Thanks again!
Oscar

Since you are doing a monolithic solve with newton, I would suggest changing the aux  variable/aux kernel to a functor material, so
[FunctorMaterials]
    ...
    [populate_hydro_pressure]
      type = ADParsedFunctorMaterial
      property_name = hydrostatic_pressure
      functor_names = 'T'
      use_xyzt = true
      expression = '-${alpha} * ${g} * ${rho} * y * (T - ${reference_temperature}) + ${outlet_pressure}'
      block = 'coolant'
    []
    ...

since the aux kernel will drop derivatives from T

node.title: Developing custom applications
node.bodyText:
I am trying to set up my own FE formulation using MOOSE for a sandwich panel.
I have done the tutorial for developing custom application. I have gone through shell, beam, and truss kernel and material source files. Nevertheless, it is very confusing.
As a beginner user, I want to understand how to formulate my own application. For instance, I want to write a 2D truss application to practice MOOSE systems. Is there any way to learn this in a straightforward way? My goal is to learn and go back to my original sandwich panel problem.
I would appreciate any recommendations.

@cbolisetti any recommendations ?
Working with custom (truss) elements is not beginner use of the software. It's a little advanced. Those Truss objects you found are going to be your best examples

Thank you very much for your prompt response.
There are some confusing parts like useVectorTag(). I said truss since I thought that it would be trivial. :) Any recommendations is welcome. Many thanks.

I don't think I understand the application here. Are you trying to develop a material model for sandwich panels or an app? If it's an app, I am a bit confused about why you'd like to create an app for one problem?
And @GiudGiud mentioned, it might be a good idea to first use the code to solve your problem and then decide if you need an app (and what you'd like to put in that app).
If you plan to develop, creating an app is a good idea. It's the recommended way.

Yes, I want to develop an app for the sandwich panel. I have a formulation for it with different DoFs on each node, see draft.
Yes, I need to develop an app. I understand that this might not be efficient. I don't see any other way though.
Any thoughts?

An app is the right way.
I think following what was done for the truss elements is the right thing to do
@GiudGiud Thank you very much. Can you make a recommendation on which MOOSE systems to learn in general? I mean the right sequence from basic towards more advanced; something like a study roadmap. :)
@cbolisetti how did you figure out how to implement the truss / beam elements?

node.title: Constant anisotropy mobility
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I am working on phase transformation using KKS method. I am trying to implement anisotropic mobility as follows:
  [CHBulk]
    type = KKSSplitCHCRes
    variable = c
    ca = cf
    fa_name = ff
    w = w
  []
  [dcdt1]
    type = CoupledTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    v = 'c cb cf eta'
  []
  [ckernel]
    type = SplitCHWResAniso
    variable = w
    mob_name = M
    coupled_variables = 'cb cf eta'
[]
...
[Materials]
  [mob]
    type = ConstantAnisotropicMobility
    tensor = '0.1 0 0
              0   1 0
              0   0 0'
    M_name = M
  []
[]

But I am getting the following error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "mob", of type "ConstantAnisotropicMobility".

The declared non-AD material property 'M' of type 'libMesh::TensorValue<double>'
is already retrieved or declared as a non-AD property of type 'double'.

Can you please help me identifying the issue here?
Thank you
Ashish

Hello
I think you just need to make that material AD.
Try prefixing the type of the material with AD

Hello,
Can you give me some more information on how to do it? is it something related to MaterialADConverter? Can I find some example for reference?
Thank you
Ashish

If I use MaterialADConverter with input and output property name as same 'M' I am getting following error.
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "non_ad_local_damage", of type "MaterialADConverter".

The requested AD material property 'M' of type 'double'
is already retrieved or declared as a non-AD property of type 'double'.

Ashish
The MaterialADconverter is not meant for tensors. So you can't use it here
What should be the correct way to do it?

Try
Type = ADConstantAnisotropicMobility

Still same error,
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "mob", of type "ADConstantAnisotropicMobility".

The declared AD material property 'M' of type 'libMesh::TensorValue<double>'
is already retrieved or declared as a non-AD property of type 'double'.

Ok reading the error message again
You are creating the mobility as a tensor but one of the objects is requesting it as a simple number

does KKS CH bulk is causing it? If I run the example script from the website for SplitCHWResAniso it is running, but if I am using same kernels in my script it is not working. is there any other way to define the anisotrpy in kks models?
That's likely. You should check the code that kernel to see the type of the material property used in that kernel for mobility
I think the material property that is asked by SplitCHWResAniso is tensor (const MaterialProperty & _mob;) yet it still is not accepting the tensor value supplied in the input file.
What error are you getting now?

Hi,
Surprisingly it is working now. I made no changes at all. It is strange to me what might have happened before but there is no error now. Although I am not getting the results as expected, but, I think it has something to do with the way I made my input file. So at the moment there is no error.
Thank you Guillaume.
Ashish

node.title: Steady-state simulation using THM
node.bodyText:
Hello, I encountered a problem at run time with "Vector tag 'TIME' does not exist. This may occur if you have a TimeKernel in your problem but did not specify a transient executioner". When I simulated a single flow channel without junctions, THM using the Steady executioner worked without error. But for a singlel flow channel with junctions, THM using the Steady executioner failed to run.
Is it unsupported to run THM with the Steady executioner for a model including junctions? Do I have to simulate this steady-state problem using the Transient executioner by setting steady_state_dection=true?

Hello
A junction you are using must have a time kernel.
Either:
Find which junction that is and add code to prevent adding the time kernel in a steady solve
Use a transient executioner and let it run to steady state. It's the same as a steady solve in terms of results
@joshuahansel there might be a thing to change in a junction here

Thank you very much for your rapid reply! I think the first choice you given is better than the second. Using a transient executioner and let it run to steady state can get identical results, but the computing time will be longer than the Steady executioner?

@joshuahansel there might be a thing to change in a junction here

I am using JunctionParallelChannels1Phase, from which ODETimeDerivative is added by addMooseObjects as shown in its source file. From my point, a small change to this routine is gonna solve my problem, is it right?
I think so

I made a small change to addMooseObjects,  just let it omit the addition of ODETimeDerivative. For a single flow channel with junctions by using the Steady executioner, the mentioned problem was solved. But I encountered a new problem. THM got an error with the following:
0 Nonlinear |R| = 2.295593e+02
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
PC failed due to FACTOR_NUMERIC_ZEROPIVOT
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_FNORM_NAN iterations 0
Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge
I don't know what problem it is. Could you please give me some advice?

Can you try adding -pc_factor_shift NONZERO to your petsc options?
There is a troubleshooting page on our website for convergence issues
Also, maybe it could be your initial guess? I know I've tried Steady simulations with THM before and diverged with a bad initial guess, like the velocity being zero.

This unconverged problem was solved by using improved petsc options, which are recommended by the Porous_Flow module. Here is the url: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/solvers.html. Thank you two very much!

node.title: error : A 'DarcyPressure' is not a registered object.
node.bodyText:
*** ERROR ***
A 'DarcyPressure' is not a registered object.

If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically loaded library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.

I tried to create objects as problem and kernel, but always got this "not a registered object". So I copied DarcyPressure example in the tutorial, still got the same error. I created the head file(.h) and source file(.cpp) for DarcyPressure, and only changed the lineregisterMooseObject("capybaraApp", DarcyPressure); where capybara is my app name. I am using a mac system and I did make process before running inputfile.  I put the head file in include folder, and put source file in folder under src/kernels/.
Could you please help me with this?

Hello
How is capybaraapp spelled in the base/ ... app.C file?
Any mismatch, caps included, between the registering and the name of the app will get you this error
Guillaume

ok so the name of the app is correct.
Where did you place this object source file? in your_app/src/kernels?
did you re-compile since you added the object? Did the compilation complete with no error message?

Hey
GiudGiud

Is there a problem with the file format

Your file must not be getting compiled. Are you sure you are using a newly compiled executable? And that the file is inside that app s folder?
Alternatively
git commit the file
Then git clean -xfd the repository and rebuild after
